Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2014 02:34AM kjsimpson wrote: Not how my IBC presented, but that doesn't mean it isn't something to be concerned about.  The best place to start is with your doctor and a mammogram if you haven't had one in the last year or two. I didn't think breast cancer presented as a small rash either, until I became concerned that my small rash wasn't going away on it's own and saw the doctor.  Since I hadn't had a mammogram in years, I made sure I got one quickly.  That action likely saved my life.  My IBC was diagnosed about as early as IBC can be diagnosed.  That improves my survival-thrival chances considerably. Get it checked out quickly and don't live in fear.  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: When is a bruise not a bruise? LMJ62 Kicks

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 09:47PM - edited Dec 13, 2013 09:49PM by kjsimpson Sounds like those are routine baselines, desimone.  I had similar baselines and I'm the healthiest person alive with cancer.  ;-)  The doctors want to be sure that the drugs they are giving you to fight your cancer aren't also taking out your vital body components (organs, muscles, and bones). The bone scan is likely a baseline because your regime will be hard on your bones (osteoporosis (sp?)). The ultrasound... is that an ECHO for your heart?  If so, that is also likely a baseline because certain chemo drugs are also hard on the heart.  They want to make sure you don't have any complications. Once you start chemo, you will also likely get a complete blood work-up a few days before each treatment.  That lets them know that your body is tolerating the treatments.  If your counts are too low (or too high in some tests), they may postpone or adjust your treatment/dosage plan accordingly. I always ask for a copy of my blood results each time I go in for chemo.  They print a copy for me and it occupies some of my time in the chemo chair while I "dr. google" with my ipad to see what it all means.  ;-)  Somewhere in the last three months I've become more patient with all the testing and poking and prodding that comes along with treatment.  But it never stops me from asking questions.  It is my body and my future.  My doctors, PAs, and nurses, have come to know that I feel better about it when I understand it. Everyone has their own knowledge comfort zone.  Mine is to know as much as I can, pray a lot, and realize that faith is seeing the next step but sometimes not the whole staircase.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo January 6, 2014 desimone birdlover23

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 11:30PM kjsimpson wrote: Stay strong and expect the best from your team.  I have no hesitancy to remind them that every wait and every mistake cut into my time with my yet to be born grandchildren.
Posts.Title: Frustrated Cdx kjsimpson

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 11:31AM kjsimpson wrote: This was really helpful to read.  Thanks, all.  My report says I'm ER-, PR-, and HER2+. Can someone help explain the KI-67 antigen?  My score was 36, which I know is 'high'.  But what does that really mean? On a side note, this has been surreal.  10 days ago, cancer was something other people got and I would pray for them.  Now everyone is praying for me (thanks, team!).   Saw the family doc on the 14th, radiologist on the 15th (the day life took a detour), biopsies on the 16th, prelim biopsy report on the 20th (cancer confirmed), saw first specialist on the 22nd.  Now.. PET/CT Scans on Monday, MRI on Wednesday morning, Port installation on Wednesday afternoon, oncology appointment on Friday, chemo to be started as quickly as possible. I've scheduled my mental breakdown for 2-4pm this afternoon and what happens in the breakdown zone stays in the breakdown zone!
Posts.Title: ER+ PR- HER2+ Question lovewins lovewins

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 09:54PM kjsimpson wrote: Thanks.  Was your port installation smooth and easy?  I'm a bit queezy about Wednesday.  Good thing I have to do these things or I'd surely chicken out.   "Breathe" is something I've actually been practicing, lately.  Deep deep deep breaths. I took a drive this afternoon, found a safe quiet, unpopulated, place near the water and just vented many emotions. My planned emotional breakdown was a good thing because I felt much better afterwards. God is in charge.  He's delegated some things to me. I'm going to be delegating some things to doctors, nurses, and people I've never met before.  As long as everyone respects the chain of command, I'm sure we'll all get through this without a mishap.
Posts.Title: ER+ PR- HER2+ Question lovewins lovewins

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 10:16AM kjsimpson wrote: Thanks.  We all need a good meltdown from time to time.  I just prefer to schedule mine so that what happens in the breakdown zone stays in the breakdown zone. I found a great place a relatively short distance away where I won't run into people I know. From what I have researched and heard, I have lucked into the best doctors in our area. Did they do your port installation with a local or a general anesthetic?  My understanding is that they are going to knock me out before I even get to the surgery room (my preference!). Glad you are feeling better.  Have a great Sunday and get some Vitamin D.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 12:18AM kjsimpson wrote: Hang in there!  I had to push to get preliminary biopsy results today.  Full report was supposed to be in today, but at 4:45pm (when I met with my doctor), he didn't even have a preliminary.  I insisted he make a stronger effort and 15 minutes later we were reading the faxed preliminary report together. Be firm when you need to be.
Posts.Title: Frustrated Cdx kjsimpson

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 05:54PM kjsimpson wrote: Shellbell, Yup, a tough way to enter the 50's.  ;-)  I understand your emotions.  I was diagnosed two months before my 50th birthday, in August. The good news... cancer is NOT a death sentence these days.  Especially if you are ready for your most important acronym of the road ahead... KCA!!  (Kick Cancer's Arsk!!)  Five months ago I was terrified.  Thinking of six rounds of chemo, a double mastectomy, and weeks of radiation treatment was just too overwhelming! I had to compartmentalize it.  First, get the best docs on my team.  Then, get through chemo.  Now that chemo has wrapped up, I'm working on wrapping my head around the upcoming surgery.  In a few weeks, I'll wrap my head around the radiation treatment plan.  But the one driving force in all of this is that I AM Stronger than Cancer!  And so are YOU!! You got this!  And we are here for you!
